subject: OS-7522 update OpenSSH to 7.9p1 Reviewed by: Robert Mustacchi <rm@joyent.com> Approved by: Joshua M. Clulow <jmc@joyent.com>
commitMessage:
OS-7522 update OpenSSH to 7.9p1
Reviewed by: Robert Mustacchi <rm@joyent.com>
Approved by: Joshua M. Clulow <jmc@joyent.com>

comments.message:
Patch Set 1:

(47 comments)

Thanks for doing the update here, Alex.

Patch Set 6:

After testing the pubkeyplugin code, found it was always denying auth due to an internal API change with the authopts structure (it's now always required for successful auth). PS#6 is the fix.
Patch Set 7: Patch Set 6 was rebased

Patch Set 7: Integration-Approval+1

I think the testing done thus far is sufficient, and should put this back now.
Patch Set 8: Commit message was updated.
Change has been successfully merged by Alex Wilson
Is it OK for us to rely on the fact that sshbuf_ptr may return NULL, though in theory the caller shouldn't in this case because it'll cause a SEGV instead.
Unchecked sshbuf_new() return, can be NULL.
Is this comment no longer relevant?
Will we correctly handle the case where sshbuf_len fails the sanity check and returns 0?
Unchecked return values. All of the _put calls can fail.
Is this buffer supposed to contain a string? Do we need to check for sshbuf_ptr == NULL?
Is zero success in this context?
Yes (this is ultimately called by one of the postauth callbacks, and the chain of them is supposed to return 0 on success)
Should we instead be using sshbuf_get() to avoid casting or is the casting fine and expected for this. I guess we'll always be in a context where int == 32-bits?
Is this change just because the upstream changed here?
Yeah... but I think I messed this up by losing the include_sigonly argument case. I'll make it look more like upstream instead.
Do we need to worry about these sshbuf calls failing? Though I guess these are just context lines, so we probably don't.
What exactly were the semantics of KEY_RSA1? I see that it was removed, but not sure as to context or meaning.
An rsa key used for sshv1. We've dropped sshv1 support in line with upstream, so these enum values went away.
Shouldn't this just be 'b' and not &b?
Shouldn't this just be 'b' and not &b?
I guess array_append allows for more than one insertion of the same key, so we need to make sure we loop over everything and that's why we don't break here right?
Is there a reason we don't just take the last entry in the array and move it as opposed to shifting?
yeah, I think it's nice to preserve the order so that if we dump it because of an error users can see things grouped together in the way they put them in.
Is all the difference here the fact that upstream has changed this around, versus us changing what upstream has?
Maybe worth a comment about why it's pointing to pkgsrc? Can this be abused by someone who has perms to an /opt/local in a zone in any ways?
I'm pretty sure xstrdup is guaranteed to abort on failure, but it's fine to do this as well.
